sources.data_found: Twenty GPU nodes were added to the HPC cluster this month. In June, RCC staff deployed 20 new compute nodes in the high-performance cluster (HPC) with two GPU cards each. The nodes increase the GPU capabilities of the cluster by 25,360 TFlops and have the following specs: AMD EPYC 9135 16-core, 3.65GHz CPU x1; 288 GB RAM (18 GB per core); 1 TB NVME solid state storage; NVIDIA Connect-X 6 HDR 200Gbps IB network card; 2x NVIDIA RTX 4500 Ada GPUs w/24GB RAM.
GPUs and CUDA - The HPC cluster includes several GPU nodes running NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti GPU cards.
>18,000 cores and >700 nodes provide powerful and scalable HPC resources; run jobs using OpenMPI, Python, MATLAB, GPUs, CUDA and more.

The High Performance Computing cluster (HPC) at FSU is the core of our computational infrastructure. With more than 16,000 cores and over 600 compute nodes, the HPC provides a powerful and scalable computing platform for large, multithreaded, and distributed parallel computations. A portion of the HPC cluster provides GPU resources. CUDA is available for running GPU optimized code.
Each GPU node contains 4 NVIDIA GPU cards. Research groups can purchase Spear systems for dedicated use if desired.
173 Total Graduate Students; 431 Applied; 222 Accepted; 60 Enrolled; 64% International Breakout; Male (76%) Female (23%); 38 Total faculty.
The department offers MS in Computer Science, MS in Cyber Criminology, and PhD in Computer Science degrees.
Florida State University has a total enrollment of 43,234 including 32,217 undergraduate students and 11,017 graduate students.

student_data.notes: Graduate CS count (173) from Peterson's data which shows 173 Total Graduate Students in the CS Department. This includes both MS and PhD students. Based on typical program ratios and 60 new enrollees annually, estimated 50 PhD students within the 173 total. Undergraduate CS count estimated at 600 based on: FSU total undergrad enrollment 32,720 (Fall 2024), typical CS major enrollment at public research universities (~1.5-2% of undergrads), and CS being among top 50 public CS programs. The 600 estimate represents ~1.8% of total undergrads.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: 20 nodes × 2 RTX 4500 Ada GPUs = 40 GPUs total. Deployed in June 2024.
Several GPU nodes mentioned but exact count not specified.

gpu_resources.notes: FSU RCC HPC has >700 nodes and >18,000 cores total. Confirmed GPU resources: 20 new GPU nodes added in June 2024, each with 2x NVIDIA RTX 4500 Ada GPUs (24GB VRAM) = 40 RTX 4500 Ada GPUs total. Older documentation mentions 'several GPU nodes running NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti GPU cards' and that 'Each GPU node contains 4 NVIDIA GPU cards' but specific counts not provided. No H100, A100, or other modern datacenter GPUs found in available documentation.

analysis_notes: Data collected December 2025. FSU HPC cluster has significant CPU resources (>18,000 cores, >700 nodes) but limited modern GPU resources based on available documentation. Only confirmed GPU deployment is 40 RTX 4500 Ada GPUs added in 2024. Student counts: 173 graduate CS students confirmed; undergraduate and PhD breakdowns estimated based on typical ratios.
